abstract.text: Send push notifications to a device to signal changes from your server.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Using push notifications to signal changes

inlineContent.text: You can signal changes by sending push notifications from a remote server, using the
push type. When the system receives the notification, it automatically calls the
method with the specified identifier. It also delivers the notification to any

To use push notifications, you start by generating the signing key for your app. Next, you configure your app to receive push notifications. Finally, you send the notifications from your server. The following sections describe each step.
Avoid sending unnecessary push notifications. If you send too many, Apple Push Notification service (APNs) throttles your requests.

For open files and directories, try to send push notifications only when your File Provider extension has an active enumerator for that item. This means your extension must update your server whenever an enumerator is created or invalidated. Additionally, this coordination must gracefully degrade when an internet connection is unavailable or fails.
For items in the working set, the server should always send push notifications.
To signal changes from a remote server, you use provider authentication tokens (not provider certificates). To create an APNs key for your app, see
. Use the APNs key to sign your JSON Web Tokens (JWT) when sending notifications from your server.

content.text: Enable and register for push notifications

inlineContent.text: To receive notifications, you first enable push notifications in your app. You can register to receive push notifications in either your app delegate or in your file provider extension. Finally, you send the device token to your server.
First, enable push notifications in your iOS app (not your File Provider extension). For details, see
Open the Capabilities pane for your app target.
Then, register for push notifications. You can register in your app delegate, your File Provider extension, or both.

If you only register for push notifications in your app delegate and the device token changes, your app won’t receive notifications until someone launches the app. Registering in the File Provider extension means your app can update the device token the next time anyone interacts with the File Provider extension’s content.
type pushes. These notifications are automatically handled by the system instead.
instance, extract the value of its
property, and send it to your server. This value is an app-specific device token. Your server uses the device token to request push notifications for this device.

code: // Send the device token to your server here.

inlineContent.text: You’re now ready to send a push notification. Start by creating a JWT; for details, see
. You can reuse the JWT as long as it remains valid.
Then send a POST request to the APNs server with the following values:
. This token is the device token you sent to your server from your
. The bundle identifier is your app’s bundle identifier.
The POST request’s content is a JSON dictionary that specifies the container and domain for the updated content. Set the container identifier to the unique string used in the container’s
to update the root container, or
, always set the container identifier to
. The system automatically propagates any working set changes to the user interface, without requiring you to signal individual containers. It ignores any other identifiers.

abstract.text: Respond to push notifications related to your app’s complications, file providers, and VoIP services.
An object that encapsulates the device token you use to deliver push notifications to your app.
A unique device token to use when sending push notifications to the current device.
The methods that you use to handle incoming PushKit notifications and registration events.
Tells the delegate that the system invalidated the push token for the specified type.
Tells the delegate that a remote push notification arrived.
Tells the delegate that the system updated the credentials for the specified type of push notification.
A push type for file provider updates.
Tells the delegate that the launch process is almost done and the app is almost ready to run.
An extension other apps use to access files and folders managed by your app and synced with a remote storage.
Alerts the system to changes in the specified folder’s content.
A File Provider extension in which the system replicates the contents on disk.
Create enumerators to specify your file provider’s content, and track changes to that content.
Build a File Provider extension that hosts and manages the user’s local files.
Create an enumerator to track changes to your file provider’s content.
